newsitem.title: FRANCE: French weekly fined over dead Mitterrand pictures.
newsitem.headline: French weekly fined over dead Mitterrand pictures.

text.p: A Paris court fined the weekly Paris-Match 100,000 francs ($20,000) on Monday for publishing two photographs of the late French president Francois Mitterrand, taken secretly as he lay on his deathbed.
It also ordered the weekly to pay each member of the Mitterrand family a symbolic one franc (20 cents) in damages for violating their privacy.

The photographs showed Mitterrand's body, dressed in a dark suit and tie and hands crossed on his stomach, in the Paris apartment where he died a year ago on January 8, after leaving office following two seven-year terms as head of state.

Mitterrand's widow Danielle, her two sons Jean-Christophe and Gilbert, and the late president's illegitimate daughter Mazarine Pingeot had filed suit against "persons unknown" in an effort to discover who took the photographs.
The court turned down their demand that the magazine publish an apology. The family had argued that publication of the photos was immoral and "ran counter to the respect due to the dead".
Prosecutor Francois Cordier had asked the court to rule that publication of the clandestine pictures had "gone over the limit", violating France's strict privacy laws.
Paris-Match has declined to name the photographer and said it was simply fulfilling its journalistic obligations.
The pictures had a historic value, and Mitterrand had while he was alive given an implicit green light for them to be taken, the magazine argued.

"Public figures do not constitute a category of different beings, for whom the importance of their actions should lead to the absence of elementary rights valid for all individuals," the court said in its ruling.
Paris-Match's refusal to name the photographer "clearly suggests the pictures were of fraudulent origin".
But the court did not order the weekly, as is usually the case in such affairs, to publish its findings as requested by the Mitterrand family.
"The court notes that the prejudice caused by the publication of the photographs was of short duration," the findings said.
"Only a few weeks after the publication of the photographs, several members of the Mitterrand family agreed to give Paris-Match interviews or to be featured in (the weekly)," the court said.
